Issues.Title: Add routing enhancements
Issues.Body:
Attempts to add some functionality from #293 

- Makes route resolving to a path a virtual method
- Adds 404 handling via virtual method, defaults to a fallback route parameter
- Adds error handling via virtual method, defaults to a fallback route parameter
- Cache components per assembly
- Allow adding and removing of assemblies from router

One important change was that RouteTables cannot be cached per assembly, as the order of the routes inside the table specifies the matching order, meaning instead the routes must be cached (route collection) and then merged and ordered. 

At the moment the unit tests etc have not been updated, only the core logic just to see what you think.

In the future if an error occurs elsewhere inside the application, it might be an idea to hook into the "handleerror" method to route to an error page. For now it just handles routing errors.

The adding and removing of assemblies should also make implementing lazy loading of application modules possible in the future.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add routing enhancements" (#1595)

I'm using CookieAuthentication with a client-side blazor app. Works great.

When I switch the app to server-side "`services.AddServerSideBlazor`" everything works fine except the Authentication cookie  doesn't get created on the browser. Which I assume is expected behaviour? 

What seems strange is that the user at that point can still access the protected api until the browser is refreshed (manual F5). So it does live somewhere. I might be wrong but I reckon it's something to do when the signalR connection terminates and reconnects and that the cookie is created on another process?

Any ideas how I would go about getting the same behaviour on server-side?
I hope it makes sense. I'll try and explain better or submit a git sample if it doesn't make sense. 

TIA

Issues.Title: Build warning: WARNING: dotnet found on the system PATH
Issues.Body:
> Using KoreBuild 2.2.0-preview1-20181001.1
> WARNING: dotnet found on the system PATH is 'C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe' but KoreBuild will use 'C:\Users\cloud\.dotnet\x64\dotnet.exe'.
> WARNING: Adding 'C:\Users\cloud\.dotnet\x64' to system PATH permanently may be required for applications like Visual Studio or VS Code to work correctly.

<del>Won't this have improper side-effect on Visual Studio or VS Code?</del>

> Adding 'C:\Users\cloud\.dotnet\x64' to system PATH permanently may be required for applications like Visual Studio or VS Code to work correctly.

<del>Are you sure? I think it will made Visual Studio or VS Code to work __incorrectly__ because of the ambiguity between 'C:\Users\cloud\.dotnet\x64' and 'C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe'!</del>

So, according to [the wiki](https://github.com/aspnet/AspNetCore/wiki/Building-from-source), the originally installed dotnet SDK ('C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe') should be removed completely and the one installed by _build.cmd_ ('C:\Users\cloud\.dotnet\x64') should be used instead. I hope this could be handled more properly.

Environment: Win10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Build warning: WARNING: dotnet found on the system PATH" (#1587)

Issues.Title: "Fixed" mode and E2E tests for <CascadingValue>
Issues.Body:
This is a follow-up to #1545.

It's a perf optimization that allows the framework to skip the subscription tracking and parameter snapshotting that it normally has to do when cascading parameters might change value. The intended use case is for things like "form context" or anywhere you do:

    <CascadingValue Value=this>...</CascadingValue>

... because if the `Value` instance is constant for the lifetime of the `<CascadingValue>`, we can make this really cheap.

If developers fail to apply this optimization when they could, nothing bad happens. We only expect this optimization to be used by our framework components and more advanced component authors who have proactively read docs about this.

**Also, E2E tests**

It was convenient to chain the E2E tests for cascading parameter/value in general to this PR. As usual, the E2E tests are not meant to cover every possible combination of use cases and error scenarios (that's in the unit tests); the E2E tests are a representative sample of high-level common scenarios.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR ""Fixed" mode and E2E tests for <CascadingValue>" (#1566)

Issues.Title: Request: Configurable folders to serve the client from
Issues.Body:
Right now in Blazor, unless you specify "_framework", the server is going to try to send you index.html - if the URL is "bad".

(See: 
https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/blob/master/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server/Builder/BlazorApplicationBuilderExtensions.cs#L162)

It would be useful to be able to configure the URLs from which the framework will be serviced.  ie - If I specify a bad URL, I would rather my server send a 404 than deliver a couple of megabytes of framework before deciding to render the default page.

Ideally, a "strict" mode would return only for the root URL (whatever it may be) and all other URLs would be at the server-side leisure for what to return.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Request: Configurable folders to serve the client from" (#1567)

Issues.Title: async BlazorComponent Lifecycle methods return null
Issues.Body:
The async lifecycle events return null instead of a completed task. This means that when you override one of those methods and Visual Studio automatically adds a `base.OnInitAsync()` you get a null reference exception, but without any real hint about where it's coming from (I only figured it out with help from someone on gitter).

The answer in this case is to not call `base.OnInitAsync()` because the method is defined as
```
protected virtual Task OnInitAsync()
    => null
```

I think it would be better to return a completed task
```
protected virtual Task OnInitAsync()
    => Task.CompletedTask;
```

And I would be willing to sift through the solution looking for places where we're returning null and should be returning a completed Task, but don't want to submit a PR if there is some reason I don't understand that returning null there makes more sense despite the confusion it caused me.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "async BlazorComponent Lifecycle methods return null" (#1576)

Issues.Title: When tracing dependencies *without* linking, don't fail the build if there are unresolved dependencies
Issues.Body:
There are legitimate use cases for referencing BCL assemblies that *aren't* in the Mono WebAssembly BCL, particularly for Blazor-on-the-server which runs on CoreCLR (and hence supports a broader BCL) anyway.

Developers can already do this themselves if they are using the linker (by passing `--skip-unresolved true` to the linker). But before this PR there was no way to get around the problem if you're not using the linker, which you typically aren't for server-side Blazor.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "When tracing dependencies *without* linking, don't fail the build if there are unresolved dependencies" (#1574)
